awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: The Ecological Impact of Mixotrophic Algae in a Changing Arctic Marine Climate
awd_abstract_narration:
Most organisms meet their carbon and energy needs solely on photosynthesis (phototrophy) or solely on ingestion/assimilation of organic substances (heterotrophy). However, there is increasing recognition that mixotrophs, which combine phototrophy and heterotrophy in a single organism, are important components of planktonic food webs.  Based on prior work, the investigators have confirmed the ubiquitous nature of mixotrophs in Arctic and Antarctic waters and hypothesize that a possible consequence to the warming of Arctic surface waters is that pico- and nano-mixotrophs will become more abundant in the region.  Using water samples from across the Arctic, the investigators will conduct laboratory experiments to better understand the environmental conditions that trigger mixotrophic activity.  Such experiments will also provide information on how the microbial food web will function in a warming climate and how such changes will potentially affect higher trophic levels, such as fish. This work will provide a possibly transformative re-orienting of our current view of surface water food webs structure and dynamics and nutrient flows in a changing Arctic.  The project will train a post doctoral scientist, graduate, and undergraduate student.  In addition, the project includes outreach to local schools in urban Philadelphia, and collaboration with a Falmouth, MA. high school art teacher as part of novel art-science projects (STEAM).

As Arctic water temperatures warm, the investigators predict a two-fold effect on the marine food web.  First, they predict an increased contribution to primary production from pico- and nano-phytoplankton.  Second, they predict an impact on bacterial consumption owing to the fact that many of the pico- and nano-phytoplankton species exhibit mixotrophic behavior.  The investigators propose a number of laboratory experiments on strains of algal groups that have been identified as mixotrophic species and are found in Arctic waters.  Arctic marine isolates will be acquired from the Roscoff Culture Collection and the National Center of Marine Algae.  Species specific mixotrophic activity and grazing rates will be determined across a range of environmental conditions that trigger and/or stimulate mixotrophy, such as high/low light and high/low nutrients.   From these species specific measurements, along with qPCR analysis to determine species abundances in water samples from across the Arctic marine environment, the potential impact of mixotrophic activity can be assessed on an Arctic-wide basis.  Finally, to determine and compare the levels of mixotrophic activity in environmental samples without relying on ingestion experiments the investigators will develop a gene-based method of activity based upon RNA sequencing and the results of the environmental response experiments discussed above.  This will be important for prediction in a warmer world.

por.por_cntn:
Most organisms get nourishment and energy from either photosynthesis (like plants) or by ingestion of some sort of food (like animals). However, some organisms, notably many single-celled aquatic algae (phytoplankton) can combine photosynthesis and ingestion of food particles in a process termed “mixotrophy.” The warming and increased melting of seasonal ice in the Arctic Ocean has led to greater photosynthetic production, and potentially to a shift to smaller phytoplankton, many of which are capable of mixotrophy.

One aim of the work supported by this grant was to better understand how climate-driven shifts in temperature and light would affect photosynthesis and ingestion in mixotrophic phytoplankton from the Arctic. While the rate of photosynthesis predictably increased with increasing light levels for all five species of phytoplankton examined, the physical factors affecting their rates of ingestion differed. Ingestion rates by four species, Dinobryon, Pyramimonas, Pedinella and Helicopedinella were not affected by the level of dissolved nutrients. However, light levels affected their feeding differently. Dinobryon had higher ingestion rates at the intermediate light level, Pyramimonas feeding was unaffected by light level, while Pedinella and Helicopedinella had higher ingestion rates at the highest light level tested. Of the four isolates of another species, Micromonas, each from different areas of the Arctic, only one strain ingested bacteria at all.

A second aim was to relate grazing rates to the abundance of the Arctic species determined using quantitative PCR (qPCR) and environmental DNA samples previously collected throughout the Arctic to estimate grazing impact. QPCR assays were developed for Dinobryon, Pyramimonas and Pedinella. A general eukaryote assay to provide relative abundance with respect to overall copy number of the ribosomal targets. Unfortuntately, it was not possible to analyze the archived Arctic samples in a Canadian colleague’s lab due to Covid restrictions on travel.

The third aim was to evaluate differential gene expression in cultures where grazing was high/active versus low. Transcriptomes were generated and analyzed for Dinobryon, Pyramimonas, Pedinella and Ochromonas. KEGG pathways with annotated transcripts upregulated in the mixotrophic condition include fatty acid degredation (Ochromonas, Dinobryon, Geminigera), lysosme/phagosome/endocytosis (Ochromonas,Geminigera, Dinobryon, Pedinella), peroxisome (Ochromonas, Dinobryon), and ubiquitin mediated protein degredation (Geminigera, Pedinella, Pyramimonas). Some taxa upregulated the same transcripts (e.g. cathepsin by Dinobryon and Pedinella, and CoA dehydrogenase by Ochromonas and Dinobryon), but there were no transcripts upregulated in common by all of the mixotrophs. Despite this, because different taxa do show specific responses, and the transcripts can be taxonomically identified, it would be possible to use some of them to assess whether specific algae were mixotrophically active in natural samples or environmental metatranscriptomes.

Because small-sized species such as these are expected to dominate warming Arctic waters and phytoplankton such as these are at the base of the oceanic food web, understanding how the ongoing environmental changes affect their growth and feeding aids in predicting the impact on higher organisms. In addition to the new scientific discoveries about mixotrophy in Arctic species, the project has provided research opportunities and laboratory training for three postdoctoral researchers, two graduate students and three undergraduate students, who all participated in various aspects of the grant. The project also disseminated new knowledge to undergraduate and graduate students through a course, Polar Ecology – Life at the Extremes” developed and taught three times during the period of the grant by Robert Sanders. The course, which reached more than 100 students thus far, included lectures, review of data collected by the principal investigators, as well as reading and individual report writing on multiple current scientific papers about polar topics.
